info.title: SUSE Best Practices Strategy and Plan
info.subtitle: Internal Only

sect1.title: Background
sect1.para: In many enterprises, a lot of hidden IT knowledge and experience exists. This is also the case for SUSE, no matter which product you are looking at.

Our consultants, sales engineers, supporters and partners work with our customers on a daily basis to implement, strengthen and fine-tune our solutions. They need to find the best options how to install third party software on top of our operating system, or to get the most out of our customers' infrastructure. Many proofs of concept and customer projects have been conducted. And many of them are at least partly documented. Also, many Technical Information Documents (TIDs) are already written and published on the Web page or in the Support Knowledgebase at , but it might be hard to find documents related to a specific topic.

Our own infrastructure department has to solve challenges, or already detected easy ways to implement a scenario which might occur similarly or might be helpful in a customer setup. One of our engineers may have detected a certain solution, which is not yet documented, to address a common problem in a repeatable manner.

This kind of information is usually buried on a personal laptop or a team server. Most of the existing documents are not in a shape that they can be published as are, because they refer to customers that we are not allowed to name or include some information that needs to be removed before publishing.
In short, a huge part of the knowledge that exists in our company is not publicly available for our colleagues, partners or customers. And if publicly available in any form, it often is hard to find.

sect2.title: Mission
sect2.para: The purpose of the &sbp; is to change this situation. We want to make existing knowledge and experience available to a broader audience, and we want to promote it via a recognizable series of documents.

sect2.title: Vision
sect2.para: With the &sbp;, we aim to introduce a new series of documents that provides reliable technical information. We want to establish a new go-to source for the usage and implementation of SUSE products and solutions, also in combination with third party software and hardware.

Our goal is to make the &sbp; series similarly prominent to the widely recognized IBM Redbooks which can be found at . We want volunteers knocking at our door to contribute and feeling honored if we pick their proposed topics for the &sbp;.

sect2.title: What Exactly Are the &sbp;?
sect2.para: In contrast to the SUSE product documentation which mainly guides through SUSE software installation and usage, the &sbp; are a series of topic-driven documentation and provide installation and implementation experiences.

A &sbp; document describes a technical scenario or solution that is not covered by the general comprehensive SUSE product documentation. Such a scenario can also include third-party software and implementations (partly) done by partners.

While our SUSE product documentation is delivered in parallel with a new product version, the &sbp; will not focus on newly launched products, but on products already introduced to and established in the market.
Usually the scenario or solution has already been implemented in a real-life scenario at a customer's site. It can include â€“ but is not limited to:

listitem.para: a specific, non-prevalent but repeatable setup
the installation of third-party software on top of a SUSE product
the implementation of a solution consisting of several products
a step-by-step procedure
a newly tested procedure
a proven process or methodology

sect2.para: &sbp; should be replicable and adaptable, they aim to save time as they use existing knowledge for further replication, and they should be sustainable and easy to update.

sect2.title: Target Audience
sect2.para: &sbp; target existing customers who work on a specific solution or must solve a concrete technical problem. We mainly address system administrators that have to set-up and implement the technical solution. &sbp; can also be of interest to technical architects as well as to technical support staff or helpdesk staff.

sect2.title: Advantages of &sbp;
sect2.para: Sharing best practices is a good way to improve performance by replicating successes throughout an organization. In addition, you can save costs through increased productivity and efficiency.
For our customers, the SUSE Best Practices provide detailed and experience-proven information about implementations that successfully work. They can also share their experiences with others.

We also want to ensure, that our colleagues (Sales Engineers, Consultants) who work on Proof of Concepts or on implementations at customer sites do not have to duplicate efforts or reinvent the wheel, but can save time and effort by capitalizing from existing documentation of similar setups.
Our sales colleagues benefit from &sbp; by being able to respond to many more customer requests much quicker.
The support teams can minimize time and effort in reproducing scenarios that already have been implemented at a customers site by other colleagues.

sect1.title: Definition of Whitepapers, Success Stories, Case Studies, Blogs
sect1.para: In addition to the product documentation, SUSE provides written material to customers which is perceived by our customers as part of the SUSE documentation, but is created under responsibility of the Marketing teams. To avoid any confusion between the purpose of the &sbp; and Marketing material, the next few paragraphs focus on the definition of these Marketing documents.

The target audience for the Marketing documents are mainly technical or business decision makers. They mostly target potential customers that do not yet run SUSE products, or customers to whom we want to upsell additional SUSE products. Marketing documents are mainly used for Demand Generation to create interest in our products and services and to build up customer relationships for the long term.

listitem.para: At SUSE we offer two different kinds of whitepapers. Technical whitepapers provide a technical overview and are mainly product focused. They contain high level technical information, for example important technical features or technologies are explained and translated into their business benefits. Business whitepapers provide a business overview of a product or solution and focus mainly on the business value.

A Success Story contains high level details of a customer project and direct quotes from the customer. It covers the problem, solution and results from a business perspective, and reveals why our customer chose our product(s) for the project.

A Case Study delivers much more in-depth technical information versus a success story. Their main purpose is to describe how a customer did benefit from the implementation of a SUSE product or solution by translating the technical information into measurable business results.

SUSE also provides a platform for a Corporate Blog at . A Corporate blog is published and used by an organization as one channel to reach its organizational goals. Corporate blogging serves multiple potential marketing goals, from driving awareness, to providing specific information, to building up relationship.

sect1.title: Prerequisites for &sbp;
sect1.para: The main purpose of &sbp; is to make knowledge that already exists (in written form) easily accessible for a broader internal and external audience. We can achieve this with the help of the documentation team via streamlined approaches and standardized processes.
This means also that the main content for a &sbp; paper is not delivered by the SUSE documentation team, but has to come from:

listitem.para: Consulting
Presales Engineers
Support
Partners
Customers
and on limited occasions also from Engineering

sect1.para: One reason why the SUSE documentation team cannot deliver the content is that we cannot reproduce the scenarios and environments implemented at our customers` sites. We heavily rely on the know-how and operating experience of our colleagues that are working directly with our partners or customers.

A minimum of 80 percent of a proposed or requested topic already needs to be available in written form. Before starting a new project, subject matter experts who worked together with a partner or customer on the implementation of the topic need to be defined, and they need to be committed to work on the paper together with the documentation team.
The content for updates of &sbp; has to come from the original content provider, or from another subject matter expert familiar with the topic, defined in advance.

sect1.title: How to Request and Contribute to &sbp;
sect1.para: A &sbp; document can officially be requested via an entry in

listitem.para: FATE
Bugzilla

sect1.para: Partners and customers can request &sbp; and participate in the creation of a document. The requirements are the same as for internal requesters.
We also accept requests for &sbp; for openSUSE. However, a topic requested for openSUSE must not conflict with any topic related to SUSE Linux Enterprise products.

sect1.title: How Does the SUSE Documentation Team Support
sect1.para: The SUSE documentation team is coordinating all requests for topics and updates. Whatâ€™s more, the team:

listitem.para: helps with finalizing the content where needed via face-to-face and phone interviews and e-mail conversations
corrects wording and fine-tuning of the content where needed
anonymizes the content anonymous, means it removes any reference to a specific customer
ports the content into the formal layout of SUSE documents and rewrites the content in DocBook XML
edits the content
coordinates proofreading
publishes the final paper on a public SUSE Web site or portal
promotes the paper via several channels

sect1.para: For writing the actual documents, the SUSE documentation team uses the official

listitem.para: The documentation team writes all content to be published in DocBook XML. This makes changes and updates easier. In addition, the &sbp; use a similar look-and-feel as the SUSE product documentation.

DAPS is a command-line tool the SUSE documentation team uses to generate output formats from the XML sources. &sbp; will be provided as single HTML (this means you can read the document from one HTML screen), PDF and ePub. It allows to run some other tasks related to writing and editing, such as a spell checker and the SUSE documentation style checker.

Git is the main version control system for the SUSE product documentation. GitHub is used as a hosting server for the sources to enable for collaboration with contributors spread over different locations.

sect1.para: The SUSE Documentation team is not delivering the general content for &sbp;. The documentation team will not test any described scenario or implementation, or validate the provided content, as it can not reproduce the scenarios.

sect1.title: Layout and Style
sect1.para: The layout and style of &sbp; follows the official SUSE documentation style guidelines and existing stylesheets. Our language and structure specifications are listed in the Style Guide.
&sbp; are provided in English only.
SUSE documentation is usually published under an open document license, such as the GNU Free Documentation License , or the Creative Commons .

This is also the case for &sbp;. We reserve the right to change the copyright of a &sbp; document to a proprietary license in cases where a key contributor has valid reasons to require this or where we see the exigency to do so to protect SUSE`s business.

sect1.title: Recognition of Authors
sect1.para: SUSE does not pay authors or contributors for the delivery of content for a &sbp; document. Nevertheless we want to recognize the efforts for the contribution to &sbp; by several means (for example, key content providers will be named as authors of a document, they will receive a limited edition SUSE or openSUSE branded business gift, etc.).

sect1.title: Distribution and Promotion of &sbp;
sect1.para: &sbp; documents will be published on an official SUSE Website (currently this is the SUSE Documentation Web page at ). They are made publicly available to everyone interested in reading these documents. SUSE reserves the right to limit the access to particular papers as a value-add only to registered customers. We plan to develop and implement a new portal for &sbp; where all papers of the series will be posted. Details for the portal are work in progress.
&sbp; will be promoted extensively via different Social Media Channels, such as

listitem.para: Twitter
SUSE blogs at
Facebook
Google+

sect1.para: A subset of &sbp; will also be used for broader Marketing purposes, such as e-mail or online programs or company-wide and product-overarching campaigns.
